stream_context.summary: Kaze focused on building the interior of a "milk-bar" saloon inside the new cowboy/desert course.  Work centred on layout (bar, stage, balcony, stair, tables), visual tricks for windows, and a hidden "chalky-milk" back-room tied to tougher Dry Bones enemies.  He also floated a separate cartridge release of the game’s soundtrack, enabled by newly-announced real-time music decompression on N64.

development_findings.summary: A new libdragon breakthrough allows real-time decompression of high-quality audio on N64; Kaze may press a standalone RTYI soundtrack cartridge.
development_findings.quote: “If the whole decompressing MP3 on N64 in real time works out, I’m probably gonna make a separate cartridge and release this with a box… sell it for like a hundred dollars.”

development_findings.summary: Saloon layout finalised: right-side bar, stage, balcony seating, swing doors, support beams, and a hidden knob-door leading to an outlaw room that serves ‘chalky milk’.
Secret room contains two Snifits and a Shy Guy; on entry they exclaim a pun (“We got caught chalky-handed”).
Lore / mechanic tie-in: Dry Bones in this level drank milk, so basic jumps no longer kill them; player must ground-pound.  An NPC delivers the hint in cowboy slang.
development_findings.quote: “Them Dry Bones up in them hills are tough as all leather… so reckon your little hops ain’t gonna make a dent.”

development_findings.summary: Hidden door blends with wall and auto-opens when Mario walks beside an unobtrusive doorknob, discovered by eavesdropping on patrons.
Kaze implemented additive-blended window decals using Biobak’s ‘combiner’ trick, but had to modify it so the multi-textured floor stays one-cycle fast.
The cowboy level currently totals ~14 k polygons split across three areas; Kaze actively manages geometry to avoid overdraw and data-transfer bottlenecks.
development_findings.quote: “The cowboy level already has like 14,000 polys right now, although it’s split over three areas… and that’s fine.”

development_findings.summary: Kaze refuses to exceed the original 8 MB N64 RAM or expansion pack limits, seeing that as ‘against the spirit of the challenge’.
development_findings.quote: “I’m not interested in ever using more than 8 MB… going beyond the original limitations is just kinda against the spirit of the challenge.”

development_findings.summary: Course re-evaluation: after re-watching a Lost Impact speedrun, Kaze feels some later RTYI themes (music level, casino, comic-book city) are uninspired; now leaning toward a moving space-station course with gravity tricks, and more ‘dream-derived’ concepts.
Course 2 interior will be overhauled: replacing a slow raft/red-coin section with a platforming sequence using newly-coded fling vines.
ChatGPT is routinely used for quick code snippets and to rewrite in-game dialogue (e.g., cowboy slang).

context_findings.summary: Kaze reports “life’s going well,” is cutting weight, and his legs hurt from heavy squats done earlier that day.
Philosophy: creation is essential to existence; he cannot imagine stopping making things.
context_findings.quote: “What would be the point of an existence where you don’t create? … Are you even alive anymore at that point?”

context_findings.summary: Stance on ROM-hacking ethics: if you hack Nintendo’s game you shouldn’t object to others hacking your hack; IP morality is already gray.
context_findings.quote: “If someone makes a hack, everyone should be allowed to use that guy’s hack… if you complain, you’re just being a little bitch.”

context_findings.summary: He deliberately stays within original N64 constraints to preserve the ‘challenge’ and authenticity.
Uses ChatGPT heavily and defends AI tools as ‘just a better Google’.

biobak.summary: Provided a window-combiner shading technique; Kaze integrates it and requests further functions.
biobak.quote: “Dude, Biobak, we need to use your window technique here… The universe aligned to make this happen.”

badub.summary: All music by Badub (Banduke) praised; Kaze plans to pay him if the soundtrack cartridge proceeds.
badub.quote: “I’m definitely gonna pay Barduke for the OST if we do end up making that cartridge.”

zeina.summary: Zeina will supply models and is animating the fortified Dry Bones; she also offers feedback on saloon textures.
zeina.quote: “Are you also doing the Dry Bones animations? … Sounds good.”

key_stories.title: Designing the Chalky-Milk Saloon
key_stories.summary: Kaze conceives a western milk-bar complete with secret outlaw room.  He iterates live on bar placement, balcony, support beams, and hidden door mechanics while crafting cowboy-style NPC dialogue with ChatGPT.
key_stories.challenge: Create a memorable hub inside the cowboy course that delivers humour, lore, and a mini-quest.
key_stories.process: On stream he sketches layout, experiments with textures and additive window decals, writes NPC lines, and settles on ‘chalky milk’ contraband guarded by Snifits.
key_stories.outcome: Spatial design locked, lore connected to gameplay (tougher Dry Bones), and clear asset assignments (Zeina animations, Biobak window combiner).
key_stories.key_quote: “Some guys aren’t satisfied with milk… they want chalky milk, so there’s gonna be a secret room where the bad guys sit around the table drinking it.”

key_stories.title: High-Fidelity Soundtrack Cartridge
key_stories.summary: A new libdragon feature may let RTYI stream compressed audio in-game.  Kaze proposes pressing a dedicated cartridge containing the full OST, packaged with box and manual, sold as a keepsake.
key_stories.challenge: N64 storage and playback limits normally force low-quality music.
key_stories.process: Kaze tracks the decompression breakthrough, discusses using Opus, plans manufacturing, and budgets paying Badub.
key_stories.outcome: Concept approved in principle; awaits tech validation before production decisions.
key_stories.key_quote: “If the real-time MP3 thing works, we’ll press a cartridge with all the RTYI songs and sell that separately.”

key_stories.title: Re-thinking Late-Game Course Themes
key_stories.summary: After watching a Lost Impact speedrun, Kaze feels some planned RTYI levels lack ‘idea density’.  He revisits his notes, discards casino and music concepts, and gravitates toward a moving space-station with gravity puzzles.
key_stories.challenge: Maintain the creativity bar set by earlier courses.
key_stories.process: Lists current ideas on-stream, critiques them, recalls how Lost Impact’s best themes came from dreams, and resolves to wait for more inspired concepts.
key_stories.outcome: Course 13–15 themes remain open, with ‘space station’ as the leading candidate; dream-inspired brainstorming will continue.
key_stories.key_quote: “We should just go with crazy themes or random things that come to me in my dreams… the space station is probably a go.”

open_questions.topic: Technical viability of real-time audio decompression
open_questions.context: Kaze referenced libdragon’s new routine but hasn’t tested it.
questions: Who on the team will integrate libdragon into RTYI?
What formats and bit-rates fit within the memory budget?
Could the same tech ship inside the main game rather than a separate cart?

open_questions.topic: Course placement and narrative role of the cowboy level
open_questions.context: Stream focused on saloon design but never stated its course number or overworld location.
questions: Which course number is the cowboy/desert area?
How does it connect to RTYI’s overall map and story arc?
Will the saloon host a mission-critical star or side objective?

open_questions.context: Design dictates they survive jumps and require ground-pounds; animations still pending.

open_questions.topic: Legal and manufacturing plan for the soundtrack cartridge
open_questions.context: Kaze floated a $100 souvenir cart but expressed concern over IP and merch partner liability.
questions: How will the team handle Nintendo IP risk?
